sect1.title: Sending Video
sect1.para: This part defines what you will send to your contact

sect2.title: Preview
sect2.para: The preview option will show you the video you are actually capturing, (The one you will send to the receiver) This enable you to validate that you are actually capturing a video feed. This is also use full to

sect2.title: Video Source
sect2.para: Here you can choose witch video source you want to use to send. Color Bar

sect2.title: Video Standard
sect2.para: PAL: Phase Alternate Line, is an analogue television encoding system used in broadcast television systems in large parts of the world. Many European country uses this standard. NTSC: National Television System Committee, is the analog television system used in most of North America, South America, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Burma, and some Pacific island nations and territories.
Note that this settings need to be the same as the one in your capture device (Camera, camcorder, etc..).

sect2.title: Aspect Ratio
sect2.para: The aspect ratio of an image is the ratio of the width of the image to its height.
Select one of these depending of what ratio the receiver need to output.

sect2.title: Video Bitrate
sect2.para: Video bitrate is the number of bits of video data that are conveyed or processed per unit of time. It is expressed in Mega bits per second. Video bitrate capabilities varies depending of the video codec used:

entry.para: 16 Mbps, seems to be limited only by CPU
Most CPU-intensive (though scales to multiple cores) and most latency.
100 kbps (will go to 500 kbps with motion)
4Mbps (generally will be stay at 3Mbps without a lot of motion)
Preferable tradeoff for CPU-cost + Latency vs. Quality.

Bitrate variable, depends largely on image source material. Doesn't like sudden, extreme changes in light (results in stuttering). Least CPU-intensive, lowest latency, reasonable quality at higher bitrate.
Quality engine is much more reliable than using the bitrate setting. Tends to stutter with static, homogenous source material (i.e. camera pointed at wall) for low quality setting.

sect2.title: Fullscreen
sect2.para: You have an option to automatically pop-up the video display in fullscreen
Press Esc or f to toggle on and off the full screen on your video output display.

listitem.para: Video flexibility and format: flexible video streams (codec, size, datarate), h264, mpeg4, h263, theora in SD format
Video input: Support video4linux2, DV, IIDC, file and possibility to select the video input.
Video standard: Possibility to use PAL or NTSC
Video framerate: Capacity to ajust the video framerate to 15, 25 and 30 fps
Video deinterlace: Possibility to deinterlace video on reception
Video scaling: Possibility to scale the video output up to 2046x2046
Video aspect ratio: Possibility to adjust the aspect ratio to 4:3 or 16:9
Video image size: Select witch size your video image is.
Video preview: Possibility to view the capture content before sending it.
Video flip: Possibility to flip the image, horizontally, vertically and rotate.
Video full screen: Option to display the video output in full screen
Video display: Possibility to set on witch display the video is output
